I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The programming discussions in 2005 between the Government of Papua New Guinea 
(PNG) and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) identified the development of Lae port as a 
potential project for ADB financing; a project preparatory technical assistance (TA) was included 
in ADB’s country strategy and program update 2005−2006.1 Responding to an official request 
sent by the Government in January 2006, the Fact-Finding Mission2 visited PNG from 21 
February to 3 March 2006. Based on extensive consultations with central and local government 
agencies,  the  private  sector,  funding  agencies,  landowners,  civil  societies,  nongovernment 
organizations, and faith and community-based organizations, the Mission defined the rationale, 
scope of study, implementation arrangements, cost estimates, financing plan, and terms of 
reference for consulting services for the TA.3 The TA will prepare the proposed Lae Port 
Development  Project—Tidal  Basin  Phase  I  for  potential  ADB  investment.  A  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
 
II.    ISSUES 
 
2.  PNG is an island country, comprising the eastern half of New Guinea and 600 other 
offshore islands. The total land area is approximately 462,000 square kilometers, accounting for 
more than 80% of the total land area in the South Pacific. Its mainland consists of rugged 
mountain ranges, fertile upland valleys, coastal plains, and extensive swamps. It has a coastline 
of more than 17,000 kilometers and 17 million hectares of reef-covered coastal waters, making 
it the largest fishing zone in the Pacific. Thirteen of the country’s 19 provinces are coastal. 
 
3.  PNG is richly endowed with mineral, forestry, and fishery resources, and eco-conditions 
for agricultural production, and enjoys proximity to Australian and Asian markets. In spite of its 
development potential, PNG’s economic and social performance, since independence in 1975, 
has been disappointing. Economic growth averaged around 3% in the 1980s and 1% in the 
1990s, and was negative from 2000 to 2002. The economy recovered in 2003 and 2004, with 
real gross domestic product (GDP) growth estimated at 2.8% and 3%, respectively, because of 
(i)  favorable  international  commodity  prices,  (ii)  resumption  of  petroleum,  gold  and  copper 
production, and (iii) improved macroeconomic management. The long period of low economic 
growth took a toll on infrastructure, social services, poverty, and law and order. Roads, wharves, 
jetties, and airstrips are deteriorating due to lack of funding for maintenance, hindering private 
sector investment. Education and health services are declining or not delivered. The incidence 
of poverty increased from 37.5% in 1996 to 54% in 2003. HIV/AIDS is spreading. In terms of the 
human development index, PNG ranked 133 out of 177 countries in 2004.  
 
4.  PNG’s economy is highly dualistic, with a small modern sector coexisting with a large 
subsistence sector. Only 15% of the population is in the modern sector, having a stable source 
of income. The rest of the population lives in rural areas, surviving on subsistence and cash 
crop  agricultural  production.  Consumption  constitutes  some  60–70%  of  GDP,  and  capital 
formation, only 12–17%. Mining and agriculture are the major industries.

5.  Due to the archipelagic nature of the country and rugged terrain, which creates widely 
dispersed  population  pockets,  limiting  mobility  and  opportunities  to  develop  the  domestic 
market,  PNG  relies  heavily  on  trade,  particularly  exports,  for  economic  growth  and  fiscal 
revenue. Exports rose steadily from $985 million in 1980 to $2,529 million in 2004; growth of 
imports was moderate. As a percentage of GDP, exports increased from 35% in 1986 to almost 
48% in 2002; during this period the percentage rose to more than 50% in some years. Imports 
as a percentage of GDP stayed close to 30%. Mineral, petroleum, and agricultural products 
such as cocoa, coffee, copper, copra, gold, palm oil, and petroleum are PNG’s major export 
items. PNG relies on imports for both capital and consumer goods.  
 
6.  The port sector provides a vital link between PNG and the world market, with more than 
80% of PNG exports shipped from ports. PNG has 22 declared ports, with numerous publicly 
and privately operated wharves, jetties, and landings. Papua New Guinea Harbours Limited 
(PNGHL), a statutory authority 100% owned by the Government, is mandated to maintain and 
operate the 22 ports; only 16 are operational. In 2004, they handled a total of 5.01 million tons 
of general cargo, and 195,000 twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs)  of containerized cargo. 
PNGHL’s net profit after tax for the year was K17,664,569.  
  
7.  The city of Lae is PNG’s industrial and commercial trade center. Lae port, the largest 
port in PNG, is centrally located and is on most Pacific shipping routes. It serves as the principal 
gateway for the highlands region, which is the most populous region in the country and richly 
endowed with natural resources including gold, oil, and gas; and eco-conditions for growing 
coffee, cocoa, and tea. PNG’s most significant road—Highlands Highway—runs from Lae to the 
highland  provinces,  bringing  the  country’s  major  export  items  to  Lae  port  and  distributing 
imports ranging from heavy machinery to food products to the region. In 2004, of the total cargo 
passing through the 16 ports, Lae port accounted for around 51% of general cargo and 56% of 
containerized cargo. About 50% of PNG exports and 90% of coffee exports are handled through 
Lae port. 
 
8.  Built in the 1930s, Lae port started as a small conventional cargo port, handling mostly 
break-bulk cargo. Since 1995, cargo throughput has been growing at an annual rate of 3.4%. 
Consistent with the container revolution in the shipping sector, container cargo has registered 
higher growth of 5% per annum, compared with general cargo, which has grown at an annual 
rate of 2.5%. The size of vessels calling Lae port for coastal trade has increased from 70−80 
meters (m) to 100−120 m, and for international trade, from 150 m to 200 m. The current cargo 
volume and vessel types calling the port require at least four international berths with a total 
length of 800 m. 
 
9.  Over  the  past  decade,  Lae  port  has  been  adapting  to  the  demands  of  container 
operations. However, the pace of investing in maintaining, rationalizing, and adding new port 
facilities has not kept pace with the growing trend toward containerization and larger ships. The 
current five berths4 at Lae, with a total length of approximately 520 m, and a total storage area 
of 52,600 square m (m2)5 for cargo marshalling, are aging and insufficient to handle increasing 
cargo volumes and ship size. Berth 4 for domestic ships is underutilized as it can no longer 
accommodate these ships. Berth 1, with a length of 123 m and water depth of 11 m, is suitable 
for overseas vessels, but was damaged by an earthquake in 2000 and is now used as a 
domestic terminal. Overseas vessels are mainly serviced by berths 2 and 3, which have a total 
length of 307 m. As a result, port congestion at Lae is frequent, imposing high costs on port

users. According to a shipping company, delays of 3–5 days have become the norm rather than 
the exception, and a 1-day delay in the harbor costs the company $20,000 per day. Some 
vessels are turning away from the port. Others are considering imposing congestion charges, 
which will translate into higher costs for importers and exporters, and eventually, consumers 
and the general economy. Port congestion also poses health and safety issues, and the issue of 
compliance with the International Shipping and Port Security Code.  
 
10.  The 15% rise in cargo volume since 2003 has stretched Lae port beyond its capacity. 
The situation is expected to deteriorate, considering the Government’s development strategy 
and  ongoing  or  potential  economic  activities  in  the  highlands  region.  In  its  Medium-Term 
Development  Strategy  (2005−2010),6  the  Government  defined  its  overarching  development 
strategy as export-driven economic growth, rural development, and poverty reduction. In line 
with  its  strategy,  the  Government  is  investing  in  rehabilitating  and  upgrading  Highlands 
Highway, and attracting investment in mining projects in the highlands region. Some gas, oil, 
gold, copper, and nickel projects are already, or will soon be, under way. The world price for 
coffee is still climbing in favor of PNG, which produces one of the best quality coffees in the 
world. All these will contribute to the growth of traffic through Lae port, increasing stress on the 
port facilities.  
 
11.  As early as the 1970s, PNGHL had a plan to expand port capacity by developing a tidal 
basin project in the swamp area to the west of the existing facilities. ADB assessed the project 
and approved a loan in 1980. Unfortunately, the project did not proceed due to an unexpected 
dispute relating to land ownership between a tribal group claiming customary landownership 
and PNGHL.7 Sluggish economic growth in the following two decades discouraged not only 
investment  in  the  tidal  basin  project,  but  also  adequate  maintenance  of  the  existing  port 
facilities. Improved economic performance and steady increase of the cargo throughput at Lae 
port since 2003 have generated revenues for the Government and PNGHL. The Government 
has allocated K15 million from the budget to extend the length of berth 3. The project is 
currently at the stage of contract award and is expected to be completed by late 2007. Using its 
own financial resources, PNGHL successfully completed the dredging in 2004, increasing water 
depth from 8 m to 13.6 m. It has embarked on a number of short-term projects, including 
constructing a new container storage area of 10,250 m2, repairing berth 1 to its original state, 
removing two sheds to expand the storage area for container cargo, and installing reefer outlets 
and a standby generator. The total investment is about K15 million. 
 
12.  The Government and PNGHL recognize that these quick solutions are necessary but 
insufficient to alleviate the bottleneck, and are seeking funding for the following subprojects: 
  
(i)  construction of a new passenger and coastal trade berth; 
 
(ii)  reconstruction of berth 1 into a full overseas container berth by backfilling the 
ponds, reinforcing hard stand, and connecting with berth 4; and 
 
(iii)  tidal basin phase I project, which includes (a) dredging and reclamation works 
involving over 2.2 million cubic meters of hydraulic fill; (b) slope protection works 
of 20,000 m2; (c) construction of an overseas berth (wharf) of 180 m; container

13.  The  TA  Fact-Finding  Mission  carried  out  an  initial  poverty  and  social  assessment 
(Appendix 2) and conducted extensive consultations with a range of stakeholders, including the 
central and local governments, private sector, funding agencies, landowners, civil societies, 
nongovernment  organizations,  and  faith  and  community-based  organizations  regarding  the 
need for and scope of the Lae port project and social risks associated with the project. The 
Mission was impressed by the enthusiasm and widespread support for the proposed project. 
The spirit of cooperation, partnership, participation, and working for the common good revealed 
during the consultations are particularly encouraging.  
 
 
III.    THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
14.  The TA aims to design and prepare the Lae Port Development Project—Tidal Basin 
Phase  I  to  support  the  Government’s  overarching  development  strategy  of  export-driven 
economic growth, rural development, and poverty reduction. The outcome will be a project 
design and feasibility study agreed to by the Government and ADB.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
15.  The TA will (i) provide a sound macroeconomic and sector context for the proposed 
investment project by critically assessing the status and prospect of PNG’s economic, social, 
and  trade  performance;  and  conducting  a  comprehensive  port  sector  analysis; 
(ii) comprehensively assess Lae port, including port facilities, services provided, operations, 
performance, efficiency, tariff structure, customs procedure, private sector participation, and 
logistic  chains;  (iii)  undertake  traffic  surveys  and  market  analysis,  and  project  capacity 
requirement for Lae port using the up-to-date modeling method; (vi) design project components 
and project performance monitoring framework, identify performance targets and socioeconomic 
impact indicators, and establish measuring mechanism; (v) update and refine the feasibility 
study for the proposed project; and confirm technical, economic, and financial viability of the 
project;  (vi)  undertake  financial  assessment,  socioeconomic  analysis  among  stakeholders, 
environmental  impact  assessment,  and  resettlement  planning;  and  ensure  financial  due 
diligence and due diligence on social and environmental safeguards, and establish baseline 
data;  (vii)  promote  public  consultations,  participation,  and  private-public  partnership;  (viii) 
explore the possibility of cofinancing; (ix) undertake site investigations, and prepare detailed 
engineering design and bidding documents; (x) establish and maintain a functional project 
implementation office; and (xi) propose financing arrangements for an ADB loan. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1.125 million equivalent. The Government has 
asked ADB to provide $900,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan  Special  Fund,  funded  by  the  Government  of  Japan.  The  Government  will  finance 
$225,000 in kind by providing office accommodation and support services, local communication 
and transport, and other services and facilities required for TA implementation. The detailed 
cost estimates and financing plan are attached as Appendix 3. The Government has been 
informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  PNGHL  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  for  the  TA.  PNGHL  will  provide  adequately 
furnished offices in both Lae (main office) and Port Moresby; and assign counterpart staff, 
including at least one engineer, to work with the international consulting team. PNGHL will also 
be responsible for coordinating and liaising with relevant government agencies and ADB. 
 
18.  The TA will require a total of 35 person-months of international (24) and domestic (11) 
consulting services to carry out the scope of the study as described in the outline terms of 
reference in Appendix 4. The areas of expertise required include port planning, port engineering 
design,  transport  economics  and  socioeconomics,  financial  assessment  and  analysis, 
environmental impact assessment, and resettlement planning.  
 
19.  The TA will be carried out by an international consulting firm in association with a 
domestic  firm  or  a  team  of  domestic  individual  consultants.  The  firm  will  be  engaged  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2006) and other arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for the recruitment of domestic consultants, using the simplified technical 
proposal procedures based on the quality-based selection method—justified because of the 
technical, economic, and environmental uncertainty associated with the project.  
 
20.  The  consultant  will  produce  the  required  outputs  and  reports  in  accordance  with 
Appendix 4, para, 13, and provide ADB and the Government with three copies each of each 
output and report. Electronic versions will also be required. 
 
21.  The TA will be implemented over 15 months on an intermittent basis, including 5 months 
for  designing  the  project  and  ensuring  due  diligence  on  technical,  economic,  financial, 
environmental,  social,  and  resettlement  viability;  and  6  months  for  preparing  project 
implementation. The TA will commence in October 2006 and end in January 2008.  
 
 
VI.   THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $900,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Papua New Guinea for preparing the Lae Port Development Project-Tidal 
Basin Phase I, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Papua New Guinea: 
 
According to the 2000 census, between 1980 and 2000, PNG's population grew by an annual average rate of 2.7% to 
5.19 million. Approximately half of the population is under 19 years old. PNG's population has recently suffered 
significant declines in living standards due to worsening economic performance. Poverty estimates have not been 
updated since the last household survey in 1996. Although the country does not exhibit the widespread abject poverty 
present in some developing countries, World Bank projections (2005) show the proportion of poor living under the 
national poverty line at 53% in 2003, compared with 37.5% in the benchmark year of 1996. The proportion of the 
population living on less than $1 a day is estimated to have increased from 24.6% in 1996 to 39.1% in 2003. Many 
health indicators have deteriorated in recent years, including the availability and performance of health facilities. 
Immunization and infant mortality rates have deteriorated since 1990. PNG is the only Pacific island country 
considered to have a generalized epidemic of HIV. 
 
PNG’s human development index has improved since the mid-1970s, but very slowly. In 2005, PNG ranked 137th, 
reflecting  alarming  economic  and  social  intracountry  disparities.  On  the  poverty  index  of  the  United  Nations 
Development Programme, PNG ranks 68th among developing countries. It ranks last among Pacific developing 
member countries on both indexes, with great challenges in achieving the Millennium Development Goals. PNG's 
main social indicators, such as life expectancy and maternal and child mortality rates, show improvements since 1975, 
but are still well below the averages for lower middle-income countries. PNG still has limited primary health care. 
Infectious diseases are claiming many lives, and serious public health risks result from endemic diseases such as 
malaria and the ever-increasing HIV/AIDS epidemic. A general HIV epidemic is under way, with prevalence rates 
among 15–49 year-olds at 3–4% in Port Moresby, well over 2% in other urban areas, and over 1% in rural areas. In 
education, the rate of participation in primary schooling is improving, but it remains lower than in most other countries 
in the region. 
 
Most of the population lives in rural communities based on the traditional village structure and depend on subsistence 
farming supplemented by cash cropping. Only 15–20% of Papua New Guineans live in the main urban areas of Port 
Moresby, Lae, Madang, Mt Hagan, and Goroka. PNG has a relatively small dual economy, comprising a formal and 
informal economy. The formal economy is dominated by large-scale resource projects, particularly in mining and 
petroleum, and provides a large proportion of government revenue. The informal economy supports 85% of the people 
through  semi-subsistence  agriculture.  The  formal  sector  employs  around  15%  of  the  workforce.  PNG  has  an 
abundance of natural resources, including (i) large reserves of minerals; (ii) extensive forestry and fishery assets; 
(iii) significant potential for agricultural expansion; and (iv) many locations with potential for ecological and cultural 
tourism. Despite the potential of these resources, PNG's economic performance has fallen short of expectations. 
Economic growth has not kept up with population growth and performance varies considerably from year to year.  
 
The proposed Lae port project is in line with the Government’s Medium Term Development Strategy, which highlights 
the importance of export-driven economic growth, rural development and poverty reduction, and the priorities set forth 
in the (draft) national poverty reduction strategy, which is structured around five pillars: (i) strengthen governance, 
(ii) increase development of land and natural resource, (iii) improve and maintain physical infrastructure, (iv) improve 
and expand economic growth opportunities, and (v) strengthen and expand social services. The project will contribute 
to export-led economic growth and income generation by improving port infrastructure. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   General Intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
The project preparatory TA consultant will carry out a socioeconomic and poverty assessment among stakeholders 
and prepare gender-disaggregated socioeconomic and poverty profiles for project stakeholders, with information on 
employment status (with emphasis on gendered division of labor), asset and resource ownership, income data, 
degree of skills and knowledge base, social cohesion, and community organization. Critical needs and constraints 
faced by local communities in fully benefiting from the employment and business opportunities associated with the 
(anticipated) increase in road and port traffic and connectivity, as well as their ability to respond to the inherent health 
and /or HIV/AIDS risks associated with the road rehabilitation and/or upgrade will also be assessed.

C.   Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
ADB’s TA Fact-Finding Mission identified a broad range of stakeholders including central and local governments, 
business community, and landowners. The TA consultant will conduct an additional stakeholder analysis.  
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes     No 
 
ADB’s TA Fact-Finding Mission was consultative and participatory, involving a broad range of stakeholders including 
central and local government agencies, private sector, landowners, international and local nongovernment 
organizations, faith-based groups, women’s associations, and community-based organizations. The TA consultant 
will follow good practice in line with the terms of reference during socioeconomic analysis, resettlement planning, and 
project design. 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
The project is not expected to cause any specific cultural or social impact on or exclude any socioeconomic group, 
including women, from benefiting from the project. The project will identify practical modalities to maximize benefits to 
communities (especially women and other vulnerable groups) and mitigate health risks associated with increased 
road and/or port traffic and connectivity. If women are adversely affected during resettlement, the resettlement plan 
will include ways to mitigate these adverse effects. All data collected will be gender-disaggregated.

Including land transportation and essential equipment, to be procured under the Asian Development Bank’s 
Procurement Guidelines, and whose ownership will be transferred to Papua New Guinea Harbours Limited 
upon completion of the technical assistance. 
c  Including technical site investigations and socioeconomic surveys. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

Appendix 4  11
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES 
 
1.  An international consulting firm in association with a domestic consulting firm or a team 
of domestic consultants will be recruited to provide a total of 35 person-months of consulting 
services. The scope of services will include but not necessarily be limited to the following. 
 
A.  Macroeconomic and Sector Analysis 
 
2.  The consultant will undertake the following activities: 
 
(i)  Assess the economic and social performance of Papua New Guinea (PNG) since 
its independence in 1975 through field visits and secondary information. Review 
PNG’s economic and trade data; analyze its economic structure; identify sources 
of  growth;  and  evaluate  the  role  of  foreign  and  coastal  trade  in  generating 
economic  growth,  employment  opportunities,  revenue  for  the  Government, 
income  for  individuals,  and  other  economic  and  social  benefits.  Identify 
incentives  for  foreign  and  coastal  trade,  taking  into  account  international 
commodity  price  trend  and  the  Government’s  development  strategies  and 
policies. Assess PNG trade prospects (foreign and coastal) and trends. 
(ii)  Review the Government’s transport sector development strategy, analyze the 
traffic patterns, and critically assess the role of the port sector in promoting trade 
and other aspects of social and economic development. 
(iii)  Conduct a comprehensive port sector analysis for PNG. Assess PNG’s port 
sector development status, constraints and potential, port sector performance, 
institutional structure and capacity, regulatory framework, and financial resources 
and management; the Government’s sector policies, strategies, and regulations 
(notably tariff and competition policy); private sector participation; and the role of 
Lae port in the sector.  
(iv)  Identify areas of improvement that could be assisted by the Asian Development 
Bank  (ADB).  Propose  options  for  private  sector  participation  and  loan 
conditionality on sector issues.  
 
B.  Analysis and Assessment of Lae Port 
 
3.  The consultant will undertake the following activities: 
 
(i)  Review the range of services provided by Lae port, its functions, and its role in 
the international and coastal trade. 
(ii)  Review the performance of Lae port during the last 3 years, including traffic 
volume, financial performance, productivity, and efficiency; and identify issues. 
(iii)  Conduct  operational  analysis.  Examine  the  adequacy  of  existing  facilities, 
efficiency  of  the  use  of  the  existing  facilities,  and  operational  systems  and 
practices. Identify issues and make recommendations.

(v)  Review port maintenance policy and sources of funding. Identify issues and 
make recommendations.

12  Appendix 4 
(vi)  Review Lae port’s management and operational systems. Assess institutional 
and human capacity. Identify issues and make recommendations. 
(vii)  Undertake traffic surveys and market analysis, including shipping lines, type and 
volume of cargos, existing sources of traffic, potential new sources of traffic, 
traffic directions, growth pattern, and competition with other ports and modes of 
transport. 
(viii)  Project traffic demand for Lae port, taking into account the present and potential 
future  role  of  Lae  port  in  international  and  regional  shipping  and  its  role  in 
domestic transport network; prepare commodity-specific cargo projections for 
20–25 years, utilizing a rational method of port demand forecasting consistent 
with long-term growth patterns of economies and trade in the region and realistic 
assessment of the future pattern of growth in break-bulk and container cargo; 
and carry out a simulation study to identify capacity requirements for Lae port. 
(ix)  Conduct logistics analysis. Identify the inbound and outbound logistic chains for 
the  movement  of  the  major  commodities/cargos.  Determine  the  performance 
parameters of the chains; and the time, cost, and losses associated with the 
movement. Recommend areas of improvement. 
(x)  Assess the current systems and procedures for customs clearance, identify ways 
to  streamline  operations  and  reduce  transaction  time,  and  recommend 
standardized  documentation  and  simplified  procedures  that  could  be 
incorporated into the current customs clearance systems. 
(xi)  Review  the  current  status  of  private  sector  participation  in  the  production 
activities at Lae port, assess investment requirements for Lae port, and promote 
private-public partnership in developing and maintaining Lae port. 
(xii)  Critically  review  the  Master  Plan  for  Lae  Port  by  Netherlands  Engineering 
Consultants  during  1960–1970,  and  the  Feasibility  Study  Report  and  Final 
Design Report for Lae Port Project done by Nedeco-Haskoning consulting firm in 
association with Maunsell PNG Pty Ltd. in 1980 and 1981. Establish the need for 
the proposed tidal basin phase I project. 
 
C.  Financial Assessment of Papua New Guinea Harbours Limited 
 
4.  The consultant will undertake the following activities: 
 
(i)  Undertake  the  financial  management  assessment  of  Papua  New  Guinea 
Harbours Limited (PNGHL). Complete ADB’s financial management assessment 
questionnaire, financial management internal control and risk assessment, and 
financial  management  assessment  report,  where  necessary,  making 
recommendations for institutional strengthening of financial management as part 
of a time-bound action plan. 
(ii)  Assess  the  acceptability  of  proposed  accounting  policies,  including  financial 
reporting standards and general accounting practices. Work with counterparts to 
propose reporting formats and timetables. Assess suitability of auditing standards 
and  auditors,  and  propose  auditor  arrangements,  including  auditor  terms  of 
engagement. Identify potential accounting, reporting, and auditing issues; and 
propose practical corrective options.

Appendix 4  13
(iii)  Review financial statements to assess historical (a) financial performance, (b) 
retail  tariff  levels,  (c)  equity  and  financing  arrangements,  and  (d)  whether 
sufficient internal funds have been generated to sustainably support ongoing 
operations (i.e., to service existing debt and to finance a reasonable proportion of 
capital expenditures). 
 
D.  Preparation for the Tidal Basin Phase I Project 
 
1.  Public Consultation, Socioeconomic Analysis, Poverty Assessment, and 
Project Design and Monitoring Framework 
 
5.  The consultant will undertake the following activities: 
 
(i)  Establish with PNGHL a consultative and participatory process at the project 
preparatory  technical  assistance  stage  that  will  continue  throughout  project 
design, construction, and operation. 
(ii)  Identify project stakeholders in Lae port services and the city of Lae through a 
consultative process; conduct public consultations on the proposed Lae port tidal 
basin project; identify beneficiaries and vulnerable groups; and incorporate their 
needs, to the extent possible, into the project design. 
(iii)  Prepare gender-disaggregated socioeconomic and poverty profiles for project 
stakeholders.  Collect  data  through  statistical  records;  field  surveys;  and 
interviews  with  key  stakeholders,  such  as  government  officials,  women’s 
federations,  business  associations,  and  civil  society  associations.  The 
information should include population, income levels, occupations and division of 
labor,  unemployment,  education  levels,  health  conditions,  and  other  relevant 
data.  Information  should  be  gender-disaggregated.  The  profiles  should  be 
comprehensive  to  serve  as  the  baseline  for  the  socioeconomic  performance 
indicators.  
(iv)  Conduct a poverty and social analysis in accordance with ADB’s Handbook on 
Poverty and Social Analysis1 and Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact on 
Economic  Analysis  of  Projects.2  Assess  poverty  incidence  based  on  the 
Government’s and internationally accepted poverty lines.  
(v)  Assess the socioeconomic impacts of the project, including impacts on poverty, 
gender,  indigenous  people,  vulnerable  groups,  and  sexually  transmitted 
infections/HIV/AIDS. Prepare detailed social and poverty impact assessment and 
a summary of poverty reduction and social strategy in accordance with ADB 
guidelines. Propose mitigation measures to minimize project negative impact and 
ways to maximize project benefits. 
(vi)  Prepare  a  report  on  public  participation,  providing  details  on  consultation 
meetings; and prepare a table of external assistance to the port sector based on 
the consultations with the funding agencies. 
(vii)  Propose  project  rationale,  components  (including  physical  and  institutional 
aspects), and project design and monitoring framework; and identify project risks. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
                                                 
1 ADB. 2001. Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis. Manila. 
2 ADB. 2001. Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact Assessment on Economic Analysis of Projects. Manila.

14  Appendix 4 
(viii)  Propose a project design and monitoring framework. Identify project performance 
targets and socioeconomic impact indicators, prepare a gender-disaggregated 
socioeconomic baseline data, and establish a measurement mechanism. 
 
2.  Engineering Study and Design 
 
6.  The consultant will undertake the following activities: 
   
(i)  Critically  review,  assess,  and  update  the  Feasibility  Study  Report  and  Final 
Design Report for Lae Port Project done by Nedeco-Haskoning consulting firm in 
association  with  Maunsell  PNG  Pty  Ltd  in  1980  and  1981  and  detailed 
engineering design, if available. Conduct further site investigations, including but 
not  limited  to  soil  and  hydrographic  conditions,  and  ascertain  the  technical 
viability of the project. 
(ii)  Prepare detailed engineering design, contract packages, and bidding documents; 
propose an implementation schedule; and prepare a procurement plan for the 
project in accordance with ADB requirements. 
(iii)  Investigate and assess the port construction sector, including the number of 
contractors, qualifications, and level of competition. 
(iv)  Propose terms of reference for construction supervision and staffing schedule, 
and prepare bidding documents for construction supervision consulting services. 
 
  3.  Cost Estimates and Project Financial Analysis 
 
7.  The consultant will undertake the following activities: 
 
(i)  Investigate  project  inputs,  sources  of  materials,  quantities,  and  unit  rates. 
Prepare reliable cost estimates for the project, including base cost, physical and 
price contingencies, and other financing charges during construction. Propose 
drawdown  schedules,  and  compute  price  contingencies,  interest,  and  other 
financing  charges  in  accordance  with  the  Guidelines  for  the  Financial 
Governance and Management of Investment Projects Financed by the Asian 
Development Bank. In preparing the base cost, separately identify the foreign 
and local cost components; taxes and duties, if any; the environmental mitigation 
costs; and land acquisition and/or resettlement costs. 
(ii)  Prepare the financial projections for the project over 20–25 years, in accordance 
with the national financial accounting procedures and regulations and in the 
formats acceptable to ADB, including balance sheets, income statements, and 
cash-flow  statements  in  nominal  terms.  Two  years  of  historical  financial 
information should also be presented. 
(iii)  Carry  out  financial  evaluation  by  calculating  the  financial  internal  rate  of 
return, using proposed tariffs and comparing it with a weighted average cost 
of capital in accordance with the Guidelines for the Financial Governance and 
Management of Investment Projects  Financed by the Asian Development 
Bank.  The  financial  internal  rate  of  return  and  weighted  average  cost  of 
capital should be computed on an after-tax basis in real terms. Undertake 
sensitivity tests to assess the effects of adverse changes in key assumptions 
that  underline  the  financial  analysis,  including  tariffs,  project  costs,

Appendix 4  15
implementation period, overall projected traffic volume, and a combination of 
these factors. 
(iv)  If  onlending  is  necessary,  explore  with  the  Government  the  lending  and 
onlending arrangements, terms and conditions of onlending, and mechanism 
for the flow of the ADB loan; and agency responsibility of the loan repayment. 
(v)  Explore possibility of cofinancing with other funding agencies, particularly with 
the Australian Agency for International Development. 
 
4.  Project Economic Analysis 
 
8.  The consultant will  
 
(i)  carry  out  economic  analyses  for  the  project  in  accordance  with  ADB's 
Guidelines  for  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects,  by  comparing  with-  and 
without-project scenarios;  
(ii)  assess the impacts of the project on poverty reduction and income generation; 
(iii)  derive the economic costs, taking proper account of taxes and duties, tradable 
and nontradable as well as shadow rates for labor, wages, local materials, and 
local equipment; 
(iv)  identify project benefits, including quantifiable and unquantifiable benefits to the 
general economy; 
(v)  detail the complete set of assumptions in the calculation of project benefits and 
costs, together with justifications and a clear description of the with- and without-
project scenarios; 
(vi)  calculate the net present values and economic internal rates of return over the 
study period (20–25 years) and their sensitivity to changes in costs, benefits, 
implementation  delays,  and  trade  growth  as  well  as  a combination  of  these 
factors; 
(vii)  elaborate project risks, and measures to mitigate these risks; and  
(viii)  undertake least-cost analysis by comparing alternative designs. 
 
5.  Environmental Impact Assessment (6 person-months) 
 
9.   The consultant will assess the environmental impact and prepare the environmental 
impact assessment (EIA) in accordance with ADB’s Environment Policy (2002), Environmental 
Assessment  Guidelines  (2003),  Operations  Manual  Section  F13  on  Environmental 
Considerations in ADB Operations (2003), and comply with the Government's environmental 
assessment requirements and procedures. The EIA should also follow the World Bank Sectoral 
Guidelines on Port and Harbor Facilities, as presented in the Technical Paper Number 14C: 
Environmental Assessment Sourcebook, Volume II; and the International Finance Corporation’s 
Environmental, Health and Safety Guidelines for Port and Harbor Facilities. 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
                                                 
3  ADB. 2003. Operations Manual. Section F1/BP (Environmental Considerations in ADB Operations). Manila (29 
Oct), para 1.

16  Appendix 4 
10.  The scope of the consultant’ work will include but not be limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Gather secondary data on the physical environment, ecological resources, and 
the quality-of-life values of the project area and other affected areas; undertake 
field survey and quantitative sampling on, but not limited to, (a) proposed project 
areas particularly the dredging, quarry, and borrow sites (flora/fauna) and marine 
environment including estuaries and coral reef, and screen for the presence of 
fisheries resources including spawning and nursery areas, rare, threatened, or 
endangered  species,  and  other  ecologically  sensitive  issues;  (b)  alternative 
assessment of the disposal sites of dredged materials including biophysical and 
social  assessment;  (c)  baseline  information  including  physical  and  chemical 
analysis of air quality, water quality (inland and offshore), noise, and sediment 
contaminants; and (d) modeling on change in tidal bore, river circulation, and 
salinity that may affect shoreline integrity and induced coastal erosion. 
(ii)  Based on activities in (i), assess (a) the environmental impacts of the project 
covering physical, biological, sociocultural, and economical aspects, as well as 
both  direct  and  indirect  impacts  during  preconstruction,  construction,  and 
operation, including those due to induced impacts within the foreseeable future, 
and their cumulative impacts; (b) assess associated environmental impacts of the 
project;  and  (c)  develop  specific  mitigation  measures  with  community 
involvement.  
(iii)  Undertake consultations with the affected people and other stakeholders in the 
project area during the EIA study to explore their perceptions and acceptance of 
the project. Present the record of public consultations in the EIA and or summary 
EIA in a table format indicating dates, agencies and/or institutions, participants, 
major issues discussed, and conclusions. Assist PNGHL in preparing materials 
for public disclosures and consultations as required by PNG’s Environmental Act 
2000.  
(iv)  Prepare an EIA report and summary EIA according to ADB format and guidelines 
covering an environmental management plan and the monitoring plan; assist 
PNGHL to comply with the Environment Act 2000, including in EIA reporting, 
submission,  and  clearance  (from  the  Department  of  Environment  and 
Conservation). The EIA report should recommend (a) measures to safeguard the 
environment during preconstruction, construction, and operational phases of the 
project;  (b)  mitigation  measures  and  the  monitoring  program,  including  cost 
implications, and an institutional setup for undertaking the program; and (c) the 
responsible  agencies  for  environmental  monitoring  during  project 
implementation,  including  recommendations  for  external  and/or  independent 
monitoring (suggested institutions and cost estimate). 
(v)  Assess the institutional capacity of PNGHL and other agencies concerned in 
implementing the proposed environmental management plan. Where necessary, 
propose necessary training to enable PNGHL to implement the environmental 
management plan and monitoring plan.  
(vi)  Assess past and present climate data (particularly rainfall, temperature, wind, 
and sea level); based on it, (a) prepare country-level climate risk profiles that 
show  the  likelihood  of  extreme  weather  and  climate  events  and  interannual 
variations, and how these may change in the future due to global warming; 
(b) assess the impact of climate change on the project; and (c) recommend

Appendix 4  17
adaptation measures to climate change in project design, including costing of the 
adaptation measures. 
 
  6.  Resettlement Planning (6 person-months) 
 
11.  The consultant will undertake the following activities: 
 
(i)  Conduct a socioeconomic and poverty assessment of project-affected people,4 
gender analysis, and a survey of least 10% of affected people and 20% of 
seriously  affected  people  to  understand  the  existing  economic  and  social 
condition  of  those  affected,  and  provide  a  basis  for  eligibility  criteria  and 
entitlements for compensation and other assistance. 
(ii)  Together with PNGHL, (a) conduct consultations with those affected to reflect 
their  views  in  formulating  the  compensation  and  rehabilitation  measures; 
(b) prepare  a  resettlement  information  booklet  containing  measurement  of 
losses, detailed asset valuations, entitlements and special provisions, grievance 
procedures, timing of payments, and displacement schedule; and (c) distribute 
this to all affected people. 
(iii)  Prepare a resettlement plan in accordance with ADB’s involuntary resettlement 
policy5 and Operations Manual6 on involuntary resettlement. The consultant may 
refer to ADB’s Handbook on Resettlement7 as a guide. The resettlement plan 
should  include  (a)  a  statement  of  involuntary  resettlement  objectives  and 
strategy;  (b) organizational  responsibilities;  (c)  community  participation  and 
disclosure arrangements; (d) findings of the socioeconomic survey and social 
and  gender  analysis;  (e)  legal  framework,  including  eligibility  criteria  and  an 
entitlement  matrix;  (f)  mechanisms  for  resolution  of  conflicts  and  appeals 
procedures;  (g)  identification  of  alternative  sites  and  selection;  (h)  inventory, 
valuation  of,  and  compensation  for,  lost  assets;  (i)  landownership  tenure 
acquisition  and  transfer;  (j)  access  to  training,  employment,  and  credit;  (k) 
shelter,  infrastructure,  and  social  services;  (l)  environmental  protection  and 
management; (m) monitoring and evaluation; (n) a detailed cost estimate with 
budget provisions; and (o) an implementation schedule.  
(iv)  Disclose the resettlement plan to those affected and obtain the Government’s 
endorsement at the end of 3 months of service.  
 
7.  Project Management Office 
 
12.  The consultant will 
 
(i)  Establish and maintain a functional project implementation office in Lae and Port 
Moresby, consisting of qualified staff in the areas of port engineering, financial
